Bad Practices in Python

Oct 29, 2018

Here I am taking notes of the some bad practices I’ve had with Python and how to write better code.

  • Never write out the absolute paths of folders.

It is often the case that people need to run one script across multiple operating systems. While Linux and MacOS use forward slashes in the path, Windows use backslashes. As a result, the absolute path I wrote on my Mac won’t run on a Windows machine. Python makes it easy that we can use modules like os.path.join, os.sep.path.join, or pathlib.path. These modules will use the correct slashes for the current operating system you are using. Here is an simple example of os.sep.path.join:

  • Break up long lines of codes.

No one likes to read a really long line of codes. We can use \ to help break up split one line into multiple lines.

  • Don’t loop over data frames.

Looping over data frame is usually slow and not efficient. If possible, loop over lists and tuples, and then combine/convert everything into a data frame after looping.
